text: Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( MTb ) , the causative agent of tuberculosis ( TB ) , is the most common co-infection and cause of death in patients infected with human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) [ 1 ] , [ 2 ] .

Direct engagement of pathogen recognition receptors ( PRRs ) by MTb on mononuclear phagocytes activates signaling cascades that directly induce transcription from the proviral LTR ( reviewed in [ 3 ] ) .

Furthermore , inflammatory cytokines and chemokines produced by the human host in response to MTb infection activate signal transduction pathways in <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> T cells and monocytic cells that also result in transcriptional activation of the HIV-1 LTR [ 4 ] - [ 6 ] .

Activation of HIV-1 replication via these MTb - induced pathways ultimately leads to higher viral loads and , in turn , expedited <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> T cell loss and progression to AIDS ( [ 7 ] , reviewed in [ 8 ] - [ 10 ] ) .

Furthermore , the progressive immune compromise associated with HIV-1 infection itself is a major cause of latent MTb reactivation , as well as increased susceptibility to primary TB infection ( [ 11 ] - [ 15 ] , reviewed in [ 8 ] ) .
The primary PRR on monocytic cells triggered by MTb infection is <extra_id_0> toll-like receptor (TLR) 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 16 ] - [ 20 ] .

Engagement of <extra_id_0> TLR2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> results in engagement of the adaptor protein <extra_id_0> MyD88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and the subsequent recruitment of several kinases , including <extra_id_0> IRAK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IRAK4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and the ubiquitin ligase <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( [ 21 ] - [ 23 ] , reviewed in [ 10 ] , [ 24 ] ) .

<extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activates IkappaB kinase ( IKK ) and mitogen - activated protein ( MAP ) kinases that , in turn , ultimately induce activation of specific transcription factor families , including the NF-kappaB and AP-1 families , which have been shown to associate with the HIV-1 LTR and to drive its transcription ( [ 22 ] , [ 25 ] - [ 27 ] , reviewed in [ 10 ] ) .
Notably , HIV-1 comprises several subtypes , and the LTR of each subtype is unique with respect to the number and organization of activator binding sites .

For example , HIV-1 subtype B , the most highly characterized viral subtype and the primary cause of infection in the Americas , Europe , Japan , and Australia , has two tandem NF-kappaB motifs in its LTR .

By contrast , HIV-1 subtypes C and E , which have spread disproportionately in TB-burdened sub-Saharan Africa and southeast Asia , have three and one NF-kappaB binding sites , respectively [ 1 ] , [ 28 ] - [ 30 ] .

We previously showed that the most primordial member of the nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) family , <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( also known as <extra_id_0> TonEBP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , binds to a site within the HIV-1 LTR that is highly conserved across all HIV-1 subtypes , and is also conserved in HIV-2 and SIV LTRs .

This NFAT5 site overlaps the core NF-kappaB binding motifs in the LTR and is required for constitutive replication of representative HIV-1 subtype B , C , and E isolates in human primary monocyte-derived macrophages ( MDM ) [ 31 ] .

Given that <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has previously been shown to be transcriptionally activated by the MAP kinase p38 , which is downstream of <extra_id_0> MyD88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling , [ 32 ] , we speculated that <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may also be involved in MTb - induced activation of HIV-1 replication via a TLR - mediated pathway in monocytes and peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) .

Here , we show that <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and its cognate binding site are of crucial importance for efficient MTb - induced stimulation of HIV-1 replication in human MDM and PBMC .

Moreover , we demonstrate that MTb infection increases <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression in human monocytes in a <extra_id_0> MyD88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent manner .

Thus , these results expand the known stimuli of <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression to the PRR - mediated innate immune response , and demonstrate that <extra_id_0> NFAT5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a critical modulator of MTb - induced enhancement of HIV-1 replication .
